Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Wave Carpet Ocean Demonstration
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase 1 project enables the development and validation of a fully operational hydraulic Power Conversion Chain (PCC) designed specifically for an ocean Wave Energy Converter (WEC). A WEC's PCC is responsible for converting absorbed mechanical power to electrical power. Ocean wave energy is currently an underutilized resource that has the potential to become an important part of a renewable energy mix providing power up to a third of the US while reducing carbon emissions alongside with wind and solar power. However, device survivability is a key challenge that has thus far held the wave energy industry back. This project includes the testing and validation of various hydraulic safety mechanisms, advancing the PCC as part of a broader strategy for WEC survivability.


This STTR Phase 1 project will directly support the development and validation of a Power Conversion Chain (PCC) as part of a larger effort to design, construct, and test a full-scale Wave Energy Converter (WEC) prototype in an ocean deployment. The PCC will be tested using a hardware-in-the-loop approach, in which a computer simulation of the WEC is coupled directly to the physical PCC elements. This real-time feedback will allow the PCC's performance to be evaluated for realistic ocean wave climates, and will facilitate rapid testing of critical safety mechanisms using the actual components in a safe laboratory environment. Results from the tests will be compared with a high-fidelity computer model of the PCC to validated performance. Once proven, the PCC will be incorporated into a revolutionary WEC design, which offers superior storm survivability and power consistency.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of California, Berkeley, Mechanical Engineering

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean wave energy is currently an underutilized resource that has the potential to become an important part of a renewable energy mix, reducing carbon emissions alongside wind and solar power. The Electric Power Research Institute estimates that that the total US recoverable wave energy resource could supply up to a third of US electricity needs. A wave energy converter (WEC) is a device that is capable of harnessing this energy and converting it into electricity. The power conversion chain (PCC) is the WEC subsystem responsible for converting absorbed mechanical power to electrical power and includes the power take-off (PTO), which is the element that absorbs energy from the oscillating WEC, effectively dampening its motion. This STTR Phase I project focused on the development of a hydraulic PTO and PCC.

CalWave designed and constructed a scaled proof of concept prototype PCC that incorporated both, a controllable PTO and temporary energy storage architecture. To achieve this architecture, the PCC design included separate accumulators at different pressure levels. By engaging and disengaging these accumulators, the PTO applies discrete steps of constant force and can track a desired force trajectory. The performance of this PCC was evaluated using a state-of-the-art hybrid simulation scheme co-developed with our research partners at UC Berkeley Mechanical and Civil Engineering. Hybrid simulation allows a physical PCC to be tested while coupled to a computational model of the WEC so that it experiences the same operating conditions it would in various sea states. This real-time feedback allowed the PCC's performance to be evaluated for complex realistic ocean wave climates and facilitated the testing of critical safety mechanisms using actual components in a safe laboratory environment.

Additionally, a computational model consisting of individual PCC components was developed to predict the performance of the entire subsystem. The simulation was used to evaluate the effectiveness of various control strategies and to size PCC components. Prior to this project, calculations of the total efficiency of the WEC from wave to electricity were limited to using an average PCC efficiency for all sea states. As a next step, the PCC simulation model can be coupled with simulations of the WEC hydrodynamics, providing to a holistic understanding of WEC behaviour for further performance and cost optimization.

The experience gained in working with hydraulics at this scale is critical to advancing our WEC to a commercial product. This project gave us a better understanding of the tradeoffs inherent in hydraulic PTO designs vs other PTO types, both from a practical perspective and with regard to overall WEC performance. In addition, as an STTR, this project allowed us to further develop CalWave’s research partnership with UC Berkeley Civil and Mechanical Engineering and learn from their expertise. This not only made our solution more effective but will allow us to extend these learnings moving forward. Further product development may include increasing the number of accumulators to achieve additional discrete damping steps, further improving the achievable force trajectory.


Last Modified: 02/23/2018
Modified by: Marcus Lehmann

Further product development may include increasing the number of accumulators to achieve additional discrete damping steps, further improving the achievable force trajectory.
